'''Neal Pattman''' (January 10, 1926 – May 4, 2005)<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2005.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2005 - January to June |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] harmonica player, singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p34424/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Neal Pattman|author=Jason Ankeny|publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> Sometimes billed as '''Big Daddy Pattman''', he is best known for his self-penned tracks, "Prison Blues" and "Goin' Back To Georgia".  In the latter, and most notable stages of his long career, Pattman worked with [[Cootie Stark]], [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], [[Dave Peabody]], [[Jimmy Rip]], [[Kenny Wayne Shepherd]], [[Guitar Gabriel]], and [[Lee Konitz]].<ref name="Dead"/><ref name="Obit"/>

==Biography==
Pattman was born in [[Madison County, Georgia]], [[United States]], one of fourteen children.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Dead"/> He learned harmonica playing from his father, after an accident involving a wagon wheel at the age of nine left him with only his left arm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.musicmaker.org/artists_profile/Neal-Pattman |title=Neal Pattman |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Musicmaker.org |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> Inspired by [[Sonny Terry]]'s playing and distinctive whoops and hollers, Pattman played on the street corners of nearby [[Athens, Georgia]].  He found regular employment in the [[University of Georgia]]'s kitchens, and gained further experience and local adoration for his regular live performances at various [[nightclub|clubs]] and [[music festival|festivals]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://onlineathens.com/stories/050705/new_20050507054.shtml |title=Neal Pattman: 1926-2005, Athens loses a music icon |author=Don Nelson |date=May 7, 2005 |work= |publisher=Onlineathens.com |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref>  However, his more general renown was minimal until 1989, when he performed at the [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]] in [[New York City|New York]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Obit"/>

A meeting in 1991 with Tim Duffy, of the [[Music Maker (label)|Music Maker Relief Foundation]], led to Pattman playing with [[Cootie Stark]], supporting [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], on a nationwide Blues Revival Tour.<ref name="AMG"/>  Playing with the [[British people|British]] blues guitarist, [[Dave Peabody]],<ref name="Obit">{{cite web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2005/jun/11/guardianobituaries |title=Neal Pattman; One-armed harmonica virtuoso |author=Tony Russell |date=11 June 2005 |work= |publisher=Guardian.co.uk |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref> led to Pattman releasing three [[album]]s between 1995 and 2001. He also contributed to [[Kenny Wayne Shepherd]]'s album and [[DVD]], ''[[10 Days Out: Blues from the Backroads]]'' (2007).<ref name="AMG"/>

However, Pattman had already died of [[bone tumor|bone cancer]] in May 2005, in [[Athens, Georgia]], aged 79.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Dead"/>
